::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
library(tidyverse)
library(ggplot2)
library(dplyr)
knitr::opts_chunk$set(echo = TRUE)
```
:::


## Description of data 

The dataset I am using comes from Kaggle https://www.kaggle.com/datasets/kaggle/kaggle-survey-2018 and is a survey titled "2018 Kaggle Machine Learning & Data Science Survey" conducted by Kaggle to capture the current state of machine learning and data science usage, mainly at the enterprise and academic level. The dataset contains survey responses from almost 24,000 respondents from varying backgrounds. The survey contains 50 questions, including 9 demographic questions and 41 questions around machine learning and data science. The questions range from platforms and products used, and tools and methodology, barriers to entry, and more. It also asks respondents about their employee experience working in these fields. I believe that the wide array of types of questions used make this dataset a good fit for research, as there are binary and categorical variables to explore but also some that ask for explicit numeric values like what percentage of their work falls to different tasks. Having several different types of questions provide opportunities for multiple types of models to be performed.

This survey was also run in 2017, 2019, and 2020 on Kaggle as part of an annual competition where users could submit code and analysis using this public data. However, I decided to use the 2018 dataset as my focus because certain questions that I think would be really interesting to analyze were omitted in later years/the survey was shortened overall. This survey was hosted by Kaggle, open to anyone in the industry, for one week in October 2018.


Reading in the dataset --


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
final <- read_csv("_data/final_project_data.csv")
```

::: {.cell}

:::


## Research Question 

Upon doing a cursory search around this data, I see some high level executive-summary style research published about this data set, but I wasn't able to find anything focused on more specific research questions. It was more demographic data of the state of ML and Data Science. I think there is the opportunity to speak more specifically about the state of machine learning and data science, and look deeper at what tools students and employees are using versus what their time is devoted to.

Therefore, my main research questions are:

1) "What tools are being used in the context of individuals school and work?"
2) "How does an individual's background (age, career, education, etc.) impact how they navigate this tech world?"

I plan to use questions like "During a typical data science project at work or school, approximately what proportion of your time is devoted to the following?" or "What percentage of your current machine learning/data science training falls under each category?" to get exact numbers that I can correlate against demos and more general usage of tools and platforms to see if there is any connection between the work one does and the tools they use.

I am interested in this dataset because a lot of research in my career is in the machine learning space, so I am always interested in contextualizing the employee experience in these areas so that I can better understand the subject of some of my survey research. I also do more general employee engagement research in my career and I think this final is a great opportunity to try my hand at some of the correlations I would like to run at my job now but have never been able to because I don't have any prior stats knowledge.


## Hypothesis

The two hypotheses I would like to test are as follows:

1) Students are more likely to use free course and certification platforms as opposed to employees who may opt for a paid course or certification through their employer. 
2) Older or more experienced data scientists tend to spent more time on the analysis end of the process.

I will explore the results of the survey questions in conjunction with demographics in this dataset like age, education, industry, years of experience, etc.to test my hypotheses.


## Descriptive Statistics

I described my dataset at the top of this as well as discussed variables of interest in the Research Question section, but here is a little bit of exploratory code:
 

 
I can see the data contains mostly younger males, but because of the sample size can really work with lots of demographic combinations.


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
ggplot(finalf, aes(x = Q1)) +
  geom_bar() +
   labs(x="Gender")
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](abigailbalint_finalpart2_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-4-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
ggplot(final, aes(x = Q2)) +
  geom_bar() +
  labs(x="Age") +
  theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, vjust = 1, hjust=1))
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](abigailbalint_finalpart2_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-5-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::


There is also a range of coding experience in the dataset.

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
ggplot(final, aes(x = Q24)) +
  geom_bar() +
   labs(x="Years of coding experience") +
  theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, vjust = 1, hjust=1))
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](abigailbalint_finalpart2_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-6-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::

The data is split between students, tech industry employees, and other industry employees.

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
ggplot(final, aes(x = Q7)) +
  geom_bar() +
   labs(x="Industry") +
  theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, vjust = 1, hjust=1))
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](abigailbalint_finalpart2_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-7-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::

Here, I made a scatterplot showing where the amount of training from work meets the amount of time spent finding insights instead of cleaning data, coding, etc. I expected this to be much higher for those who received most or all of their training from work, but that isn't the case. I'm interested to see more about this in my hypothesis testing section.


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
ggplot(final, aes(x = Q35_Part_3, y=Q34_Part_6)) +
  geom_point() +
   labs(x="Percentage of machine learning training from work", y="Percentage of project time spent finding insights")
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr}
```
Warning: Removed 7559 rows containing missing values (geom_point).
```
:::

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](abigailbalint_finalpart2_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-8-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::

-------------------------------

1) Those who are older and therefore been programming for longer likely use the longest standing programming languages.


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
final3 <- final %>%
  drop_na(Q34_Part_6, Q25)
final3$time <- as.character(final3$Q25)
final3$anlz <- as.character(final3$Q34_Part_6)
table(final3$time, final3$anlz)
```

## Hypothesis Testing

Hypothesis 1) Students are more likely to use free course and certification platforms as opposed to employees who may opt for a paid course or certification through their employer. 

For this hypothesis, my independent or explanatory  variable will be "In what industry is your current employer/contract (or your most recent employer if retired)?" and my dependent or response variable will be the question "On which online [data science course] platform have you spent the most amount of time?". 

Here I am showing from my overall sample how many respondents use each type of platform: Free, Paid, Paid Certification, and Other. This variable is a regrouped version of the original question that asks platforms individually by name. I regrouped the idustry variable to show students vs non-students, aka those who do some sort of work/career.

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
ggplot(final, aes(x = Q37_RC)) +
  geom_bar() +
   labs(x="Platform") +
  theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, vjust = 1, hjust=1))
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](abigailbalint_finalpart2_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-17-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::


Here I am generating a data table for the students (1) vs non-students (2) so that I can perform a chi-squared test as these are two categorical variables. For the course type, free is (1), paid is (2), paid certificate but offers some free courses is (3), and other is (4).

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
final$stud <- as.character(final$Q7_RCSTUD2)
final$Q37_1 <- as.character(final$Q37_RC2)
finalhyp1 <- subset(final, final$Q37_1 != "0")
table(finalhyp1$stud, finalhyp1$Q37_1)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
   
       1    2    3    4
  1  174  276  951   54
  2  872 1523 5537  283
```
:::
:::


Here I am running the chi-squared test which is showing me that given the p-value, we have to accept the null hypothesis and say that there is not statisitcal significance enough to show that being a student predicts the type of course one would take to learn ML/programming skills. 

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
chisq.test(finalhyp1$Q37_1, finalhyp1$stud, correct = FALSE)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```

	Pearson's Chi-squared test

data:  finalhyp1$Q37_1 and finalhyp1$stud
X-squared = 3.2056, df = 3, p-value = 0.361
```
:::
:::


Here I am generating a bar chart to display my results. It's tricky because the sample size of students is much lower than non-students, but we can see that the proportions are actually relatively similar. Platforms that offer paid certificates are actually most popular between both groups. 


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
table <- data.frame(with(finalhyp1, table(stud, Q37_1)))

ggplot(table, aes(x=stud,y=Freq, fill=Q37_1))+
  geom_bar(stat="identity",position="dodge")+
  scale_fill_discrete(name = "Courses Used",labels = c('Free','Paid', 'Paid Certificate'))
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](abigailbalint_finalpart2_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-20-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::

Here I am fitting a model with the same two variables. Again, I can see the p-value is not statistically significant.

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
finalfit <- final %>%
  drop_na(Q37_RC)
```
:::

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
fit1 <- lm(Q37_RC2 ~ Q7_RCSTUDY + Q7_RCSTUDN , data = finalfit)
summary(fit1)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```

Call:
lm(formula = Q37_RC2 ~ Q7_RCSTUDY + Q7_RCSTUDN, data = finalfit)

Residuals:

(Intercept)  2.636762   0.007945 331.897   <2e-16 ***
Q7_RCSTUDY  -0.028515   0.020481  -1.392    0.164    
Q7_RCSTUDN         NA         NA      NA       NA    
---
Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1

Residual standard error: 0.7201 on 9668 degrees of freedom
Multiple R-squared:  0.0002005,	Adjusted R-squared:  9.704e-05 
F-statistic: 1.938 on 1 and 9668 DF,  p-value: 0.1639
```
:::
:::



I think a problem with this may be the variance in sample size, as show below.

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
ggplot(data = finalfit, aes(x = Q7_RCSTUD, y = Q37_RC)) +
  geom_point() +
geom_point(position = "jitter")+
    geom_smooth(method = 'lm')
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr}
```
`geom_smooth()` using formula 'y ~ x'
```
:::

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](abigailbalint_finalpart2_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-23-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::

If I try and fit an additional model with income as predictor variable as well considering students are likely to have lower income, it does not help the p-value at all.

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
fit2 <- lm(Q37_RC2 ~ Q7_RCSTUD +Q9, data = finalfit)
summary(fit2)
```

## Diagnostics


Expand the description of the data with visualizations, e.g. scatter plots among key
variables, box and whisker plots, histograms etc.
• Incorporate feedback from first part
This section should then move on to regression analysis to test your hypothesis. It should include
the following:
• Hypothesis testing:
o Identification of the response variable, explanatory variable, and the control
variables
o If you are adding any interaction terms or transforming variables, an explanation
as to why you did it
o Result of the hypothesis test (and thus an answer to the research question)
• Model comparisons: Multiple models should be fit and compared in terms of
o The relationship between the explanatory variable and the response (statistical
significance) and whether it changes from model to model
o Model fit (Adjusted R-squared, AIC or BIC, PRESS statistic, etc.)
o An explanation of how the final model was chosen
• Diagnostics: Regression diagnostics for the final model
o Diagnostic plots for the final model (using the plot() function on the regression
object in R) and an explanation of what they mean
